awd_titl_txt: Research Initiation: Understanding Impacts of Soft Robotics Curricula on Female Students Engineering Identity
awd_abstract_narration:
Participation in K12 educational robotics is a common precursor to enrollment in engineering majors, however the gender gap in traditional pre-college robotics prevents equal access to these disciplines. We believe soft robotics may create a new pathway for students from underrepresented groups to enter engineering majors. Soft robots are those devices made from soft materials and flexible electronics enabling robots to more safely interface with humans and other living organisms. Soft robotics presents an opportunity to introduce traditional engineering principles through a human-centered perspective with the potential to diversify engineering. This project will address two aims. First, this project aims to understand changes in the engineering identity of middle and high school-aged female students after having engaged in soft robotics projects in their science classes. Second, this project aims to introduce the Principal Investigator to engineering education research, catalyzing a new research enterprise focused on access to engineering and educational robotics. The research team will utilize existing relationships with local schools to deliver a previously piloted soft robotics curriculum and study student experiences. Implementation will include a one-week, hands-on robotics short course for about 200 middle and high school students local to the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign.

To date, the lack of representation of women in mechanical and electrical engineering is well-documented. However, successful pathways for women to these majors are understudied. Agency beliefs have been a useful lens for understanding how women do enter some engineering majors, such as bioengineering. The mentor-mentee research team will leverage a mixed methods approach to explore soft robotics as a new pathway to engineering Critical Engineering Agency will be a framework through which to understand the student experience. The research team will use surveys and interview instruments to help answer the overall research question: How can a soft robotics implementation impact high school students’ attitudes and self-beliefs, and therefore serve as a strategy to recruit female students to traditionally male-dominated engineering majors?  Prior to the activity, students will be surveyed using engineering identity and agency belief measures. After implementation, students will complete a post-survey and the research team will interview select students to understand how the activities impacted their engineering identity. The result of this collaborative research project will be an analysis of the elements of pre-college soft robotics curriculum that may lead to diverse recruitment in engineering. Education of local stakeholders in standards-based soft robotics curriculum opens the door for further engagement in our local community. Dissemination of research results will enable broad adoption. Findings from this study will pave the way for increased representation of women and underrepresented minorities in engineering at the college level and in the engineering workforce, contributing to a diversity of solutions to society’s critical challenges. Soft robotics curricula have the potential to prepare a diverse generation of engineers and reduce the barrier to entry not only for girls, but other students from underrepresented groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Participation in K12 educational robotics is a common precursor to enrollment in engineering majors, however, the limited applications of traditional pre-college robotics limits interest in these disciplines for some students. We hypothesized that soft robotics may create a new pathway for students to develop an engineering identity and enter engineering majors. Soft robots are those devices made from soft materials and flexible electronics enabling robots to more safely interface with humans and other living organisms for applications such as wearable technologies and assistive devices. A high school soft robotics curriculum presents an opportunity to introduce traditional engineering principles through a human-centered perspective. In this study, we delivered a one-week, hands-on robotics short course to high school science students. During implementation, we surveyed and interviewed students to understand how this science-integrated robotics curriculum changed students' engineering identity and their understanding of the applications of robotics and engineering career options. We implemented this curriculum during high school at a critical timepoint in which students are making decisions about future college majors and careers. Our study included a sample size in which over two hundred high school students experienced the robotics curriculum, one hundred students participated in our survey, and thirty students were interviewed as part of this project. The results of the project are now being used to amplify the importance of early exposure to robotics to strengthen the future engineering workforce.

Our research found that despite the inclusion of engineering in K12 classrooms nationally, some subsets of engineering remain unknown to students. Traditional views of robotics include assembly lines and task-oriented designs. Bringing soft robotics to K12 students enables students to understand the nuanced application of robotics in prosthetics, wearable technologies, and agriculture. Results of our study found that even a short exposure to new engineering fields can spark career ideas in young students and positively impact engineering identity for both girls and boys who have limited initial experience. The study further identified relationships between in-school activities and at-home discussions related to engineering careers. When students brought their projects home and discussed robotics with families, we found that they were able to form connections and articulate how robotics can help family members in turn teaching their families about this new field, an activity that increased confidence for these students. Additionally, the role of dual enrollment programs in high schools was highlighted by students as a way they make decisions about career options.

We aimed to disseminate research results outside the age group and school of implementation. Five teachers were trained in the curriculum at the school of focus.  Additionally, teacher workshops and outreach events enabled dozens of teachers to be trained in the curriculum. Additionally, through outreach hundreds more students got to experience parts of the curriculum tailored for their grade level. Our curriculum was adapted, including a simplified version for elementary-aged students and an expanded version for an introductory college course. At the college level, the curriculum led to students being interested in conducting research in assistive technologies, a project that strengthened their engineering identities through human-centered design.

Collectively, these results can be used to develop K12 engineering programs to expand students’ thinking about engineering careers. These future programs can support career exploration and increase interest in science, engineering and technology for high school students. Additionally, the results of our study have created the groundwork for the study of human-centered design in K12 engineering programs to further connect engineering and technology to problems students are passionate about solving. In sum, by understanding the perceptions high school students have of the variety of available robotics careers, educators and practitioners in these fields can work together to develop new curricula that teaches young students about the variety of engineering career options available. A strong cohort of K12 students interested in engineering and robotics will strengthen the future US workforce to create technologies for all Americans and strengthen the US global competitiveness.

 


Last Modified: 04/14/2025
Modified by: Holly McIlwee Golecki
